The year when expanded medical guidelines for early allergen introduction were issued, leading to a significant increase in the rate of peanut allergy reduction in children.

keyTakeAways: The early introduction of peanut products to infants has led to a significant decline in peanut allergies, with a 27% drop after 2015 and over 40% after 2017.
About 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015, based on the implementation of early allergen introduction guidelines.
The landmark LEAP trial, led by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, showed that early exposure to peanuts reduces the risk of developing food allergies by over 80%.
Despite initial slow adoption, about 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists followed the 2017 guidelines, indicating growing acceptance.
New research from Dr. David Hill and colleagues at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia using electronic health records shows measurable reductions in food allergy diagnoses.
The current guidance (updated in 2021) recommends introducing peanuts and other allergens between four and six months of age without prior testing.
Safe early exposure methods include small tastes of peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after the landmark LEAP trial demonstrated that early exposure to peanuts in infancy reduces the risk of developing peanut allergies by over 80%, new research shows that real-world implementation of medical guidelines — first issued in 2015 and expanded in 2017 — has led to a significant decline in peanut allergy rates in U.S. children. The study, led by Dr. David Hill at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia and analyzing electronic health records, found that peanut allergy rates dropped by over 27% and more than 40% after the guidelines were introduced. Approximately 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015. Despite initial hesitancy among pediatricians and allergists, adoption has increased, and current guidance (updated in 2021) recommends introducing peanuts and other allergens between four and six months of age without screening. Experts and advocates, including FARE and dietitian Tiffany Leon, emphasize the importance of safe, small exposures such as peanut butter and yogurt to build immune tolerance.
title: Early Peanut Introduction in Infants Reduces Allergy Rates in U.S. Children
